newsitem.title: UK: Global plutonium controls may be relaxed - UK report.
newsitem.headline: Global plutonium controls may be relaxed - UK report.

text.p: Controls on plutonium at nuclear power stations could be relaxed under a plan being considered by the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), New Scientist magazine reported on Thursday.
It said the controls had been in place since 1957 and that proposals to loosen them were opposed by the United States and anti-nuclear campaigners.

"They fear it will make life easier for terrorists and rogue states who want to build atomic bombs. It also comes against a background of renewed controversy over whether reactor-grade plutonium can be used to make bombs," said the weekly science magazine.

At the root of the controversy is a suggestion by the IAEA's Bruno Pellaud that plutonium could be split into sub-groups, so that reactor-grade plutonium would require less stringent safeguards than weapons-grade plutonium.
According to the IAEA, almost 1,000 tonnes of plutonium have been created by the world's civil reactors. That is enough to make at least 125,000 atomic bombs, said the magazine.
The New Scientist said the Pellaud plan would be discussed by the agency in October.
It was proposed after complaints by France and Germany, among others, that new nuclear safeguards agreed by the agency last month were too costly and intrusive.
The stiff new safeguards were designed to avoid a repeat of the failure to spot Iraq's nuclear weapons programme before the Gulf War.
